canonical_explanation.text: A triangle is a polygon with three sides and three angles. Triangles are classified by sides (equilateral: all equal; isosceles: two equal; scalene: none equal) and by angles (acute: all <90°; right: one =90°; obtuse: one >90°). The angle sum property states that the sum of all three interior angles equals 180°.
rules: Equilateral triangle has 3 equal sides and 3 equal angles (each 60°)
Isosceles triangle has 2 equal sides and base angles are equal
Scalene triangle has no equal sides and no equal angles
Acute triangle has all three angles less than 90°
Right triangle has exactly one angle equal to 90°
Obtuse triangle has exactly one angle greater than 90°
Sum of all interior angles in any triangle is always 180°

questions.question_text: A triangle with all three sides equal is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle with all three sides equal is called an equilateral triangle. This is because 'equi' means equal, and 'lateral' means sides, so an equilateral triangle has all three sides of equal length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A, the equilateral triangle, is the correct answer. An equilateral triangle has all three sides of equal length, unlike an isosceles triangle which has two equal sides, or a scalene triangle which has no equal sides. A right triangle is a special type of triangle with one 90-degree angle, so it is not the correct answer here.

questions.question_text: A triangle with exactly two equal sides is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An isosceles triangle has exactly two equal sides, so option B is the correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An equilateral triangle (option A) has all three sides equal, a scalene triangle (option C) has no equal sides, and an acute triangle (option D) has all angles less than 90 degrees. But a triangle with exactly two equal sides is called an isosceles triangle, which is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: A triangle has angles measuring 50°, 60°, and 70°. This triangle is:
questions.explanation_correct: This triangle is an acute triangle because all three of its angles are less than 90 degrees (50°, 60°, and 70°). The angle sum of a triangle is always 180 degrees, so this triangle with angles measuring 50°, 60°, and 70° is an acute triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is not a right triangle because one of the angles is not equal to 90 degrees. It is also not an obtuse triangle because none of the angles are greater than 90 degrees. Finally, this is not an equilateral triangle because all three sides are not equal in length.

questions.question_text: In a triangle, two angles are 45° and 65°. What is the third angle?
questions.explanation_correct: In a triangle, the sum of all three angles is always 180°. Since two of the angles are 45° and 65°, the third angle must be 180° - (45° + 65°) = 70°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not add up to 180° with the given angles of 45° and 65°. Option A (60°) would make the sum 170°, which is less than 180°. Option C (80°) and Option D (90°) would make the sum more than 180°. Therefore, the correct answer is Option B (70°).

questions.question_text: A triangle with one angle equal to 90° is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle with one angle equal to 90° is called a right triangle. This is because a right angle is an angle that measures exactly 90 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Right triangle. A right triangle is a triangle that has one angle that measures 90 degrees. The other two angles in a right triangle must be less than 90 degrees. So a right triangle is not an acute triangle (all angles less than 90 degrees) or an obtuse triangle (one angle greater than 90 degrees). It is also not an isosceles triangle, which has two equal sides.

questions.question_text: Triangle ABC has sides AB = 5 cm, BC = 7 cm, and AC = 5 cm. What type of triangle is ABC based on its sides?
questions.explanation_correct: The triangle ABC has two sides of equal length (AB = AC = 5 cm), so it is an isosceles triangle. Isosceles triangles have two equal sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because an equilateral triangle has all three sides of equal length, but in this case only two sides are equal. Option C is incorrect because a scalene triangle has no equal sides, but in this case two sides are equal. Option D cannot be determined is also incorrect, as we can clearly see that two sides of the triangle are equal, so it is an isosceles triangle.

questions.question_text: In an equilateral triangle, each angle measures:
questions.explanation_correct: In an equilateral triangle, all three sides are equal in length. Since the sum of all three interior angles in a triangle is 180°, and all the angles are equal in an equilateral triangle, each angle must measure 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) 60°. This is because in an equilateral triangle, all three sides are equal in length, and therefore all three angles are also equal. Since the sum of the three angles in a triangle is 180°, and all three angles are equal in an equilateral triangle, each angle must measure 60°. The other options, 45°, 90°, and 120°, are not correct because they do not add up to 180° in an equilateral triangle.

questions.question_text: A triangle has angles 30°, 40°, and 110°. Based on angles, it is:
questions.explanation_correct: The triangle has one angle greater than 90°, which is 110°. Therefore, it is an obtuse triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The triangle has angles of 30°, 40°, and 110°. Since one of the angles is greater than 90°, it is an obtuse triangle. The other options are incorrect because acute triangles have all angles less than 90°, right triangles have one angle of 90°, and equilateral triangles have all angles equal to 60°.

questions.question_text: In triangle PQR, angle P = 55° and angle Q = 75°. What is angle R?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 50°. In a triangle, the sum of all three angles is 180°. Since we know two angles, P = 55° and Q = 75°, we can find the third angle R by subtracting the sum of P and Q from 180°: 180° - (55° + 75°) = 50°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct because they do not add up to 180° with the given angles of 55° and 75°. For example, if angle R was 40°, then the sum of the three angles would be 55° + 75° + 40° = 170°, which is less than 180°. The correct answer of 50° for angle R is the only option that satisfies the 180° angle sum property of a triangle.

questions.question_text: A triangle with sides 6 cm, 8 cm, and 10 cm is:
questions.explanation_correct: The given triangle has sides of 6 cm, 8 cm, and 10 cm. Since all three sides are of different lengths, this triangle is classified as a scalene triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because an equilateral triangle has all three sides of equal length. Option B is incorrect because an isosceles triangle has two equal sides. The given triangle has none of its sides equal, so it cannot be an equilateral or isosceles triangle. Therefore, the correct answer is option C, which is a scalene triangle.

questions.question_text: A triangle with no equal sides is called a ___ triangle.
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle with no equal sides is called a scalene triangle. This is because 'scalene' means 'uneven' or 'without equal sides', which describes a triangle where all three sides have different lengths.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'scalene'. A scalene triangle is a triangle where none of the sides are equal in length. This is different from an equilateral triangle, where all sides are equal, or an isosceles triangle, where two sides are equal.

questions.question_text: The sum of all three interior angles of any triangle is ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: The sum of all three interior angles of any triangle is 180°. This is because a triangle is a closed shape, and the sum of the angles inside a closed shape must always be 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The answer is 180°. This is because the angle sum property of a triangle states that the sum of all three interior angles in a triangle is always 180°. Even if the triangle is equilateral, isosceles, or scalene, or if it is acute, right, or obtuse, the sum of the three angles will always be 180°.

questions.question_text: In an isosceles triangle, the angles opposite to the equal sides are called ___ angles.
questions.explanation_correct: In an isosceles triangle, the two equal sides are called the 'base' of the triangle. The angles opposite these equal base sides are therefore called the 'base angles' of the isosceles triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'base' angles. In an isosceles triangle, the two sides that are equal are called the 'base' of the triangle. The angles opposite these equal base sides are called the 'base angles'. So the angles opposite the equal sides in an isosceles triangle are called the 'base angles', not the 'vertex' angles.

questions.question_text: A triangle with all angles less than 90° is called an ___ triangle.
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle with all angles less than 90 degrees is called an acute triangle. This is because the word 'acute' means less than 90 degrees, so an acute triangle has three angles that are all less than 90 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'acute'. The correct answer is 'acute' because a triangle with all angles less than 90 degrees is called an acute triangle. This is because the term 'acute' means less than 90 degrees, so an acute triangle has three angles that are all less than 90 degrees.

questions.question_text: A triangle with one angle greater than 90° is called an ___ triangle.
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle with one angle greater than 90° is called an obtuse triangle. This is because the term 'obtuse' means 'greater than 90°', so a triangle with one angle greater than 90° is classified as an obtuse triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'obtuse'. A triangle with one angle greater than 90° is called an obtuse triangle. This is because the term 'obtuse' means 'greater than 90°', so a triangle with one angle more than 90° is classified as an obtuse triangle. The other types of triangles are acute (all angles less than 90°) and right (one angle exactly 90°).

questions.question_text: If two angles of a triangle are 40° and 80°, the third angle is ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: The sum of the three angles in a triangle is always 180°. If two angles are 40° and 80°, then the third angle must be 60° to make the total 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The third angle is 60°. This is because the sum of all three angles in a triangle is 180°. If two angles are 40° and 80°, then the third angle must be 180° - (40° + 80°) = 60°. The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is a single number: 60.

questions.question_text: In an equilateral triangle, all three sides are ___ and all three angles are ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: In an equilateral triangle, all three sides are equal in length, and all three angles are also equal at 60 degrees. This is because an equilateral triangle is a special type of triangle where all the sides and angles are the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'equal, 60'. This is correct because in an equilateral triangle, all three sides are equal in length, and all three angles are 60 degrees. This is a key property of equilateral triangles - the sides are all the same, and the angles are all 60 degrees, adding up to 180 degrees in total.

questions.question_text: In a right triangle, if one angle is 90° and another is 35°, the third angle is ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: In a right triangle, the angle that is 90° (a right angle) and the two other angles add up to 90°. Since one of the other angles is 35°, the third angle must be 55° to make the total 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The third angle in a right triangle is not 45°. The sum of all three angles in a triangle is always 180°. Since one angle is 90° and another is 35°, the third angle must be 55° to make the total 180°. The accepted answer format is a single number, so the correct answer is 55°.

questions.question_text: A triangle with angles 85°, 45°, and 50° is classified as an ___ triangle.
questions.explanation_correct: The given triangle has angles 85°, 45°, and 50°. Since all three angles are less than 90°, this triangle is classified as an acute triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'acute'. An acute triangle is a triangle where all three angles are less than 90°. In this case, the angles are 85°, 45°, and 50°, which means all three angles are less than 90°, so this triangle is classified as an acute triangle.

questions.question_text: In an isosceles triangle, if the vertex angle is 80°, each base angle measures ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: In an isosceles triangle, the two base angles are equal. Since the sum of all three angles in a triangle is 180°, and the vertex angle is 80°, the two base angles must each be 50° (180° - 80° = 100°, divided by 2 is 50°).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is a single number, 50. If the vertex angle of an isosceles triangle is 80°, then the two base angles must be equal. To find the measure of each base angle, we need to subtract the vertex angle of 80° from the total of 180° (the sum of all three angles in a triangle). This gives us 100°, which we then divide by 2 to get 50° for each base angle.

questions.question_text: An equilateral triangle has all three sides equal.
questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral triangle has all three sides equal in length. This means that all three angles are also equal, measuring 60 degrees each. This is one of the defining properties of an equilateral triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some people may think that a triangle with three unequal sides is an equilateral triangle. However, this is not correct. An equilateral triangle, by definition, must have all three sides of equal length. If even one side is different in length, then the triangle is not equilateral.

questions.question_text: A scalene triangle can have two equal sides.
questions.explanation_correct: A scalene triangle, by definition, has no equal sides. All three sides of a scalene triangle must be of different lengths. Therefore, a scalene triangle cannot have two equal sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A scalene triangle is defined as a triangle with no equal sides. If a triangle has two equal sides, it is called an isosceles triangle, not a scalene triangle. For a triangle to be considered scalene, all three sides must be of different lengths.

questions.question_text: The sum of all angles in a triangle is always 180°.
questions.explanation_correct: The sum of all angles in a triangle is always 180°. This is called the angle sum property of a triangle. No matter what type of triangle it is (equilateral, isosceles, or scalene), the sum of its three angles will always add up to 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be that the sum of all angles in a triangle is not always 180°. This is not true. The angle sum property of a triangle states that the sum of all three angles in a triangle is always 180°, regardless of the type of triangle. Even if the triangle has one angle greater than 90° (an obtuse angle), the sum of all three angles will still be 180°.

questions.question_text: A triangle can have two right angles.
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle cannot have two right angles because the sum of all three angles in a triangle is always 180 degrees. If a triangle had two right angles (each 90 degrees), the total would be 270 degrees, which is not possible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not possible for a triangle to have two right angles. Each angle in a triangle must be less than 90 degrees, otherwise the total of the three angles would be greater than 180 degrees, which is not allowed. A triangle can only have one right angle (90 degrees) and the other two angles must be acute (less than 90 degrees).

questions.question_text: An obtuse triangle has exactly one angle greater than 90°.
questions.explanation_correct: An obtuse triangle has exactly one angle that is greater than 90°. This is because the sum of all three angles in a triangle must be 180°, and if one angle is greater than 90°, the other two angles must be less than 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some people may think that an obtuse triangle has more than one angle greater than 90°. However, this is not true. An obtuse triangle, by definition, has exactly one angle that is greater than 90°. The other two angles must be less than 90° in order for the sum of all three angles to be 180°.

questions.question_text: In an isosceles triangle, the base angles are always equal.
questions.explanation_correct: In an isosceles triangle, the two sides that are equal are called the congruent (equal) sides. This means the two angles opposite these equal sides are also equal. These equal angles are called the base angles of the isosceles triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some people may think the base angles of an isosceles triangle are not always equal. However, this is incorrect. By the definition of an isosceles triangle, the two base angles must be equal since the two sides are equal. The only way for an isosceles triangle to have unequal base angles is if it is also an obtuse triangle, which is a special case.

questions.question_text: If two angles of a triangle are 50° and 60°, the third angle must be 70°.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is true because the sum of all three interior angles of a triangle is always 180°. If two angles are 50° and 60°, then the third angle must be 180° - (50° + 60°) = 70°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect because the third angle of a triangle cannot be 70°. This is because the sum of all three interior angles of a triangle is always 180°. If two angles are 50° and 60°, then the third angle must be 180° - (50° + 60°) = 70°, not 70°.

questions.question_text: A triangle with angles 60°, 60°, and 60° is both equilateral and acute.
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle with angles 60°, 60°, and 60° is both equilateral and acute. This is because an equilateral triangle has all three sides equal, and all three angles equal to 60°, which are less than 90°, so it is also an acute triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. A triangle with angles 60°, 60°, and 60° is both equilateral and acute. Some students might think that if a triangle has three equal angles, it must be an obtuse triangle, but that is not the case. An equilateral triangle, by definition, has all three angles equal to 60°, which are less than 90°, so it is an acute triangle.

questions.question_text: A right triangle can also be an obtuse triangle.
questions.explanation_correct: A right triangle cannot be an obtuse triangle because a right triangle has one angle that is exactly 90 degrees. By definition, an obtuse triangle has one angle greater than 90 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A right triangle has one angle that is exactly 90 degrees. An obtuse triangle has one angle greater than 90 degrees. So a right triangle cannot also be an obtuse triangle. The two types of triangles are mutually exclusive - a triangle can be either right or obtuse, but not both.

questions.question_text: In any triangle, the largest angle is opposite the longest side.
questions.explanation_correct: In any triangle, the largest angle is opposite the longest side. This is because of the relationship between the lengths of the sides and the sizes of the angles in a triangle. The larger the side, the larger the opposite angle will be.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is not true for all triangles. While it is generally true that the largest angle is opposite the longest side, there are exceptions. In an obtuse triangle, the largest angle is greater than 90 degrees and is opposite the longest side. However, in an acute triangle, the largest angle is less than 90 degrees and may not be opposite the longest side.

questions.question_text: Arrange these angles in ascending order: obtuse angle, right angle, acute angle.
questions.explanation_correct: The angles are arranged in ascending order because an acute angle is less than 90 degrees, a right angle is exactly 90 degrees, and an obtuse angle is greater than 90 degrees. This order from smallest to largest is the correct arrangement for these three types of angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to put the obtuse angle first, followed by the acute angle, and then the right angle. This is wrong because an obtuse angle is the largest of the three, and a right angle is larger than an acute angle. The correct order is from smallest to largest, which is acute angle, right angle, and then obtuse angle.

questions.question_text: Order the steps to verify the angle sum property of a triangle:
ordering_items: Measure all three angles with a protractor
correct_answer: Measure all three angles with a protractor
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is to first draw a triangle, then measure all three angles with a protractor, add up the three angle measurements, and finally verify that the sum equals 180 degrees. This is because the angle sum property states that the three angles of a triangle must add up to 180 degrees, and you need to follow this exact process to verify it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to first add up the three angle measurements, then measure the angles with a protractor, and finally draw the triangle and verify the sum equals 180 degrees. This is wrong because you need to first have a triangle to measure the angles, and then add them up to check if the angle sum property is true.

questions.question_text: Arrange these triangles in order of increasing number of equal sides: scalene, isosceles, equilateral.
questions.explanation_correct: The answer 'Scalene, Isosceles, Equilateral' is correct because a scalene triangle has no equal sides, an isosceles triangle has two equal sides, and an equilateral triangle has all three sides equal. This order reflects the increasing number of equal sides in the triangles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be 'Equilateral, Isosceles, Scalene'. This is not correct because an equilateral triangle has the most equal sides (all three), followed by an isosceles triangle with two equal sides, and then a scalene triangle with no equal sides. The correct order is to arrange the triangles from the least number of equal sides to the most.

questions.question_text: Arrange these angle sums in the order they would appear when finding the third angle: 180°, sum of two known angles, third angle.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is 'Sum of two known angles', '180°', 'Third angle'. This is because we first add the two known angles, which gives us the sum of all three angles. Since the sum of the three angles in a triangle is always 180°, we can then find the third angle by subtracting the sum of the two known angles from 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be '180°', 'Third angle', 'Sum of two known angles'. This is wrong because we cannot find the third angle first. We need to first add the two known angles, which will give us the sum of all three angles. Only then can we subtract this sum from 180° to find the third angle.

questions.question_text: Arrange these triangles by their largest angle: Triangle A (60°, 60°, 60°), Triangle B (45°, 45°, 90°), Triangle C (30°, 50°, 100°).
questions.explanation_correct: The largest angle in Triangle A is 60°, the largest angle in Triangle B is 90°, and the largest angle in Triangle C is 100°. So the triangles arranged by their largest angle from smallest to largest are: Triangle A, Triangle B, Triangle C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A common mistake would be to think that since Triangle A has all angles equal, it has the largest angle. However, in an equilateral triangle, all angles are 60°. Triangle B has a 90° angle, which is larger than 60°. And Triangle C has a 100° angle, which is the largest of the three. So the correct order from smallest to largest largest angle is: Triangle A, Triangle B, Triangle C.

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to identify if a triangle is isosceles: Check if exactly two sides are equal, Measure all three sides, Conclude it is isosceles.
ordering_items: Check if exactly two sides are equal
correct_answer: Check if exactly two sides are equal
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is to first measure all three sides of the triangle, then check if exactly two of the sides are equal, and finally conclude that the triangle is isosceles. This is the logical sequence to identify an isosceles triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to first conclude that the triangle is isosceles, without first checking if exactly two sides are equal. You need to measure the sides first to see if two are equal, before you can conclude that the triangle is isosceles. The correct sequence is to measure the sides, check for two equal sides, and then make the conclusion.

questions.question_text: In an isosceles triangle with vertex angle 50°, order the steps to find base angles: Calculate each base angle (65°), Find sum of base angles (130°), Subtract vertex from 180° (130°).
questions.explanation_correct: In an isosceles triangle with a vertex angle of 50°, the correct order is to first subtract the vertex angle from 180° to find the sum of the base angles (130°), then find the individual base angles by dividing the sum by 2 (65°). This is because we know the angle sum of a triangle is 180°, so we can use that property to find the missing angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to first calculate the individual base angles (65°), then find the sum of the base angles (130°), and finally subtract the vertex angle from 180° (130°). This is wrong because you need to first find the sum of the base angles by subtracting the vertex angle from 180°, and then divide that sum by 2 to get the individual base angles.

questions.question_text: Arrange these triangle classifications from least restrictive to most restrictive: equilateral triangle, acute triangle, triangle.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order from least restrictive to most restrictive is 'Triangle', 'Acute triangle', 'Equilateral triangle'. This is because a 'Triangle' has the least restrictions, as it only needs to have three sides and three angles. An 'Acute triangle' has the additional requirement that all its angles must be less than 90 degrees. An 'Equilateral triangle' has the most restrictions, as it requires all three sides and all three angles to be equal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be 'Equilateral triangle', 'Acute triangle', 'Triangle'. This is wrong because an 'Equilateral triangle' is the most restrictive type, as it requires all three sides and all three angles to be equal. An 'Acute triangle' is less restrictive, as it only requires that all three angles be less than 90 degrees. A 'Triangle' is the least restrictive, as it only needs to have three sides and three angles, without any other requirements.

questions.question_text: Arrange the properties of an equilateral triangle in logical order: All angles are 60°, All sides are equal, Each angle = 180° ÷ 3.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is 'All sides are equal', 'Each angle = 180° ÷ 3', 'All angles are 60°' because in an equilateral triangle, all sides are equal first, which means all angles are also equal. Since the sum of angles in a triangle is 180°, each angle in an equilateral triangle is 180° ÷ 3 = 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order is 'All angles are 60°', 'Each angle = 180° ÷ 3', 'All sides are equal'. This is wrong because the fact that all sides are equal comes first, which then tells us that all angles are also equal. Only after knowing that all sides are equal can we calculate that each angle is 180° ÷ 3 = 60°.

questions.question_text: Order these statements about triangle angles from general to specific: The sum is 180°, In a right triangle, two angles sum to 90°, In any triangle, angles sum to a constant.
ordering_items: In a right triangle, two angles sum to 90°
In any triangle, angles sum to a constant
correct_answer: In any triangle, angles sum to a constant
In a right triangle, two angles sum to 90°
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is from general to specific. The first statement 'In any triangle, angles sum to a constant' is the most general, as it applies to all triangles. The second statement 'The sum is 180°' is more specific, as it states the exact value of the angle sum. The third statement 'In a right triangle, two angles sum to 90°' is the most specific, as it applies only to right triangles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to start with the most specific statement 'In a right triangle, two angles sum to 90°', then the general statement 'The sum is 180°', and finally the most general statement 'In any triangle, angles sum to a constant'. This is incorrect because it does not go from the most general to the most specific, which is the correct way to order the statements.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Equilateral?
questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral triangle is a triangle where all three sides are equal in length. This means that all three angles are also equal, and each angle is 60 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'all three sides equal' is the meaning of an equilateral triangle. This is because in an equilateral triangle, all three sides have the same length. The other options, 'no sides equal' and 'two sides equal', describe different types of triangles called scalene and isosceles triangles, respectively.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Isosceles?
questions.explanation_correct: Isosceles means 'two sides equal'. In a triangle, if two sides are the same length, it is called an isosceles triangle. This means that the triangle has two equal sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) Two sides equal. An isosceles triangle has two sides that are the same length, while the third side is a different length. Option B) No sides equal describes a scalene triangle, where all three sides have different lengths. Option C) All three sides equal describes an equilateral triangle, where all three sides are the same length.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Scalene?
questions.explanation_correct: Scalene means that none of the sides of the triangle are equal. All three sides have different lengths.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A scalene triangle is one where no two sides are equal. This is different from an isosceles triangle, where two sides are equal, and an equilateral triangle, where all three sides are equal. So the correct answer is A, 'No sides equal'.

questions.question_text: What is the their angle properties: of Acute triangle?
questions.explanation_correct: In an acute triangle, all three angles are less than 90 degrees. This is because the sum of all three angles in a triangle is always 180 degrees, and since none of the angles can be greater than 90 degrees, they must all be less than 90 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An acute triangle does not have any angle greater than 90 degrees, nor any angle equal to 90 degrees. All three angles in an acute triangle are less than 90 degrees. This is because the sum of all three angles in a triangle is always 180 degrees, and none of the angles can be greater than 90 degrees or equal to 90 degrees.

questions.question_text: What is the their angle properties: of Right triangle?
questions.explanation_correct: In a right triangle, one angle is equal to 90°. This is the defining property of a right triangle, where one of the three angles is a right angle (90 degrees).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The options 'All angles less than 90°' and 'One angle greater than 90°' are not the properties of a right triangle. A right triangle has one angle that is exactly 90 degrees, not all angles less than 90 degrees or one angle greater than 90 degrees.

questions.question_text: What is the their angle properties: of Obtuse triangle?
questions.explanation_correct: In an obtuse triangle, one angle is greater than 90 degrees. This is the defining property of an obtuse triangle, where one of the three angles is an obtuse angle (greater than 90 degrees).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct properties of an obtuse triangle. An acute triangle has all angles less than 90 degrees, and a right triangle has one angle equal to 90 degrees. But an obtuse triangle is defined by having one angle greater than 90 degrees, which is option B.

questions.question_text: What is the the third angle in a triangle: of 60° and 70°?
questions.explanation_correct: The third angle in a triangle with angles of 60° and 70° is 50°. This is because the sum of all three angles in a triangle must equal 180°. If two angles are 60° and 70°, then the third angle must be 180° - (60° + 70°) = 50°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 50°. The sum of all three angles in a triangle must equal 180°. If two angles are 60° and 70°, then the third angle cannot be 40° or 90° as those would make the total greater or less than 180°. The only possible third angle is 50°.

questions.question_text: What is the the third angle in a triangle: of 45° and 45°?
questions.explanation_correct: The third angle in a triangle with two angles of 45° each must be 90°. This is because the sum of all three angles in a triangle is always 180°. So if two angles are 45° each, the third angle has to be 90° to make the total 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The third angle cannot be 40° or 50°, because the sum of the three angles in a triangle must always be 180°. If two angles are 45° each, the third angle has to be 90° to make the total 180°. The correct answer is A) 90°.

questions.question_text: What is the the third angle in a triangle: of 30° and 110°?
questions.explanation_correct: The third angle in a triangle with angles of 30° and 110° is 40°. This is because the sum of the angles in any triangle is always 180°. So, if two angles are 30° and 110°, the third angle must be 180° - 30° - 110° = 40°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (90°) is incorrect because the sum of the angles in a triangle is always 180°. If two angles are 30° and 110°, the third angle cannot be 90°. Option B (50°) is also incorrect because the third angle is not 50°, but rather 40°. The correct answer is option C (40°).

questions.question_text: What unit is used for 5 cm, 5 cm, 5 cm?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) Equilateral. This is because an equilateral triangle has all three sides equal, which is the case for the given measurements of 5 cm, 5 cm, 5 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) Equilateral. A triangle with all three sides equal is called an equilateral triangle. The given measurements of 5 cm, 5 cm, 5 cm fit this criteria. Scalene triangles have no equal sides, and isosceles triangles have two equal sides, so they do not match the given information.

questions.question_text: What unit is used for 4 cm, 7 cm, 4 cm?
questions.explanation_correct: The triangle with side lengths 4 cm, 7 cm, and 4 cm is an isosceles triangle. An isosceles triangle has two sides of equal length, and this triangle has two 4 cm sides, making it isosceles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The triangle with side lengths 4 cm, 7 cm, and 4 cm is not an equilateral or scalene triangle. An equilateral triangle has all three sides of equal length, and a scalene triangle has no sides of equal length. Since this triangle has two 4 cm sides, it is an isosceles triangle, not an equilateral or scalene triangle.

questions.question_text: What unit is used for 3 cm, 5 cm, 7 cm?
questions.explanation_correct: The lengths 3 cm, 5 cm, and 7 cm are not all equal, so this triangle is classified as a scalene triangle. Scalene triangles have all three sides of different lengths.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The options A) Equilateral and B) Isosceles are incorrect because an equilateral triangle has all three sides equal, and an isosceles triangle has two sides equal. Since the given lengths 3 cm, 5 cm, and 7 cm are not all equal, the correct answer is C) Scalene.

questions.question_text: What is the the triangle classification: of 50°, 60°, 70°?
questions.explanation_correct: The triangle with angles 50°, 60°, and 70° is an acute triangle because all three angles are less than 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The triangle with angles 50°, 60°, and 70° is not an obtuse triangle, because an obtuse triangle has one angle greater than 90°. It is also not a right triangle, because a right triangle has one 90° angle. Since all three angles are less than 90°, this is an acute triangle.

questions.question_text: What is the the triangle classification: of 30°, 60°, 90°?
questions.explanation_correct: The triangle with angles 30°, 60°, and 90° is a right triangle. This is because one of the angles is 90°, which is the defining property of a right triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The triangle with angles 30°, 60°, and 90° is not an acute triangle because one of the angles is greater than 90°. It is also not an obtuse triangle because none of the angles are greater than 90°. This triangle is a right triangle, where one of the angles is exactly 90°.

questions.question_text: What is the the triangle classification: of 20°, 40°, 120°?
questions.explanation_correct: The triangle with angles 20°, 40°, and 120° is classified as an obtuse triangle. This is because one of the angles is greater than 90°, which is the defining characteristic of an obtuse triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The triangle with angles 20°, 40°, and 120° is not an acute triangle. Acute triangles have all three angles less than 90°, but in this case, one angle (120°) is greater than 90°. Therefore, this triangle is classified as an obtuse triangle.

questions.question_text: What property is used to sort "Sum of angles in any triangle"?
questions.explanation_correct: The property used to sort the 'Sum of angles in any triangle' is 180°. This is because the angle sum property states that the sum of all three interior angles in a triangle is always 180°, no matter the type of triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct property used to sort the 'Sum of angles in any triangle' is 180°, not 90° or 60°. This is because the angle sum property states that the sum of all three interior angles in a triangle is always 180°, no matter the type of triangle. The options of 90° or 60° do not represent the correct property for the sum of angles in a triangle.

questions.question_text: What property is used to sort "Each angle in equilateral triangle"?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 60°. This is because an equilateral triangle has all three angles equal, and each angle in an equilateral triangle is 60°. This property is used to identify and sort equilateral triangles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are A) 90° and C) 180°. A) 90° is not correct because an equilateral triangle does not have any right angles (90°). C) 180° is also not correct because the sum of all three angles in a triangle is 180°, not the value of each individual angle.

questions.question_text: What property is used to sort "Right angle measure"?
questions.explanation_correct: The property used to sort 'Right angle measure' is 90°. This is because a right triangle has one angle that measures exactly 90 degrees, which is a special property of right triangles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct property to sort 'Right angle measure'. 180° is the total sum of all angles in a triangle, not a measure of a single angle. 60° is the measure of an angle in an equilateral triangle, not a right triangle. The right angle measure in a triangle is 90°.

questions.question_text: What property is used to sort "Three equal angles of 60° each"?
questions.explanation_correct: The property used to sort 'Three equal angles of 60° each' is equilateral. This is because an equilateral triangle has all three sides and all three angles equal, and each angle is 60° (since the sum of all three angles is 180°).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The property used to sort 'Three equal angles of 60° each' is not scalene or isosceles. Scalene triangles have no equal sides, while isosceles triangles have two equal sides. Only equilateral triangles have all three sides and all three angles equal, with each angle being 60°.

questions.question_text: What property is used to sort "Two equal base angles"?
questions.explanation_correct: The property used to sort 'two equal base angles' is isosceles. This is because an isosceles triangle has two equal sides and two equal angles, making it the right classification for a triangle with two equal base angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) Isosceles. An isosceles triangle has two equal sides and two equal angles. This means that if a triangle has two equal base angles, it must be an isosceles triangle. The other options, equilateral (all sides and angles equal) and scalene (no sides or angles equal), do not apply in this case.

questions.question_text: What property is used to sort "No equal angles"?
questions.explanation_correct: Triangles with no equal angles are called scalene triangles. This property is used to sort them, since they have no equal sides or equal angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The option 'Scalene' is correct because scalene triangles are the ones where all three sides are of different lengths, which means there are no equal angles either. Isosceles triangles have two equal sides, and equilateral triangles have all three sides equal, so they are not 'no equal angles'.

questions.question_text: What is the the triangle type: of All three angles between 0° and 90°?
questions.explanation_correct: The triangle type where all three angles are between 0° and 90° is called an acute triangle. This is because in an acute triangle, all the angles are less than 90 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B, Obtuse, is incorrect because an obtuse triangle has one angle greater than 90 degrees. Option C, Right, is incorrect because a right triangle has one angle equal to 90 degrees. The correct answer is Option A, Acute, because in an acute triangle all three angles are less than 90 degrees.

questions.question_text: What is the the triangle type: of One angle exactly 90°?
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle with one angle exactly 90° is called a right triangle. This is because one of the angles is a right angle, which measures 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The triangle type with one angle exactly 90° is a right triangle, not an obtuse triangle. An obtuse triangle has one angle greater than 90°. In a right triangle, one angle is exactly 90°, while the other two angles are less than 90°.

questions.question_text: What is the the triangle type: of One angle between 90° and 180°?
questions.explanation_correct: The triangle type with one angle between 90° and 180° is an obtuse triangle. This is because an obtuse angle is an angle greater than 90°, and a triangle can only have one angle that is obtuse.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An obtuse triangle has one angle that is greater than 90°. This is because a triangle can only have three angles, and the sum of all three angles must be 180°. If one angle is greater than 90°, the other two angles must be less than 90°, making it an obtuse triangle. The other options, acute and right triangles, do not have any angles greater than 90°.

questions.question_text: How many does Vertex angle 40° have?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) Base angles 70° each. This is because in a triangle with one angle of 40°, the other two angles must add up to 140° (180° - 40°). Since the triangle is isosceles, the two base angles must be equal, which means they are both 70°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers A) and B) are not correct because the base angles of an isosceles triangle with one angle of 40° cannot be 60° or 40°. The total sum of the angles in a triangle is always 180°, so the two base angles must add up to 140° (180° - 40°), which means they are both 70° each.

questions.question_text: How many does Vertex angle 100° have?
questions.explanation_correct: If one of the interior angles of a triangle is 100°, then the other two angles must add up to 80° (since the sum of all three angles is 180°). Since the triangle is isosceles, the two base angles must be equal. Therefore, the base angles are 40° each.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options B and C are not correct because the base angles of an isosceles triangle with one 100° angle cannot be 60° or 70°. The base angles must add up to 80°, so they must be 40° each.

questions.question_text: How many does Vertex angle 60° have?
questions.explanation_correct: If the vertex angle of a triangle is 60°, then the base angles must also be 60° each. This is because the sum of the three interior angles in a triangle is always 180°. With one angle being 60°, the other two angles must be 60° each to add up to 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The vertex angle of the triangle is 60°, so the two base angles cannot be 70° or 40° each. This is because the sum of the three interior angles in a triangle is always 180°, and with one angle being 60°, the other two angles must be 60° each to add up to 180°.

questions.question_text: What is the value of 0 equal sides?
questions.explanation_correct: The value of 0 equal sides is a scalene triangle. This is because a scalene triangle has no equal sides, so none of the sides are the same length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) Scalene. A scalene triangle is a triangle with no equal sides, so it has 0 equal sides. Equilateral triangles have all 3 sides equal, and isosceles triangles have 2 equal sides, so they do not match the description of 0 equal sides.

questions.question_text: What is the value of 2 equal sides?
questions.explanation_correct: The value of 2 equal sides in a triangle is called an isosceles triangle. In an isosceles triangle, two sides have the same length, while the third side is different.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The option 'Equilateral' is incorrect because an equilateral triangle has all three sides equal in length. The option 'Scalene' is incorrect because a scalene triangle has no sides of equal length. The correct answer is 'Isosceles' because an isosceles triangle has two equal sides.

questions.question_text: What is the value of 3 equal sides?
questions.explanation_correct: The value of 3 equal sides is an equilateral triangle. This is because an equilateral triangle has all three sides of equal length, which means it has three equal sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An isosceles triangle has two equal sides, not three. A scalene triangle has no equal sides. The correct option is equilateral, which means all three sides are equal in length.
